channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-670] embedded: when using alternative classloader code parsing succeeds but evaluation fails
item.description:
The situation is:

0) using embedded groovy in eclipse plugin as service for projects. each project has it's own classloader different from plugin classloader (like "A" below)

1) class loader A knows about class pkg.X
2) creating GS = new GroovyShell(A)
3) creating Script instance by means of
code = "import pkg.X; ..."; // pkg.X is reffered directly
S1=GS.parse(code); - parsing succeeds

parsed script instance is required for caching to get rid of parsing overhead on further script invocations

4) now running S1.run() fails with NoClassDefFoundError:

java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: pkg.X
at Script1.class$(Script1.groovy)
at Script1.run(Script1.groovy:1)
...

Setting thread context classloader to A durin S1.run() does not affect

Seems it uses default MetaClassRegistry.loader - GroovyClassLoader(getClass().getClassLoader())

while getClass().getClassLoader() apparently knows nothing about pkg.X

— Possible Issues
1) It may be possible to keep classloader associated with particular script instance

2) It may be alternative issue to include classloader info into Binding like it's done in OGNL:

binding.setClassLoader(a)
S1.setBinding(binding)
S1.run()
item.environment: Win32, sun jdk 1.4.2_05, eclipse 2.1.2 runtime workbench
item.summary: embedded: when using alternative classloader code parsing succeeds but evaluation fails

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
There is definitely something wrong with the beta7 and beta8 releases. When I embed groovy in BEA WebLogic Server 8.1SP3 (or SP4), I am getting a NoClassDefFoundError.

Reverting to beta6 works fine. But there is something broken in beta7 and beta8, from what I can tell.
This is the issue about classloaders we talked about the other day. If you could have a look at it, that'd be great.

In a very similar situation:

GroovyClassLoader loader = new GroovyClassLoader(aClassLoader);
Class c = loader.parseClass(aScript);
Map m = new HashMap();
m.put("context", aContext);
Binding b =new Binding(m);
Script s = InvokerHelper.createScript(c,b);
s.run();

where the script depends upon loading a class which is only available
through aClassLoader but not the actual current classloader that loads
GroovyClassLoader, Binding and Script.

I find that I get a java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError on trying to instantiate the GroovyReflector:

gjdk.org.ten60.transport.http.parameter.representation.ParameterNVPAspect_GroovyReflector.invoke() line:-1
groovy.lang.MetaMethod.invoke() line:110
groovy.lang.MetaClass.doMethodInvoke() line:1372
groovy.lang.MetaClass.invokeMethod() line:316
org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.Invoker.invokeMethod() line:143
org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.InvokerHelper.invokeMethod() line:106
script1106224799635.run() line:8

In this case it doesn't work on beta-9 or beta-6.

I am unsure if this is the same bug or a different one. It appears very similar. Let me know and I can re-raise.

I run into exactly the same error:

1) class loader A knows pkg.X
2) groovy script defines a class that extends X
3) Initiliase Groovy class loader
loader = new GroovyClassLoader(getClass().getClassLoader());
3) Compile script with
Class groovyClass = loader.parseClass(new StringBufferInputStream(script));
4) crash!!! with various stack traces:

java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.objectweb.asm.ClassVisitor.visit(IILjava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/String;[Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/String;)V
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.ReflectorGenerator.generate(ReflectorGenerator.java:85)
at groovy.lang.MetaClass.loadReflector(MetaClass.java:2236)
at groovy.lang.MetaClass.generateReflector(MetaClass.java:2191)
at groovy.lang.MetaClass.checkInitialised(MetaClass.java:2138)
at groovy.lang.MetaClassRegistry.getMetaClass(MetaClassRegistry.java:117)
at groovy.lang.MetaClass.addNewStaticMethodsFrom(MetaClass.java:1284)
at groovy.lang.MetaClass.addInheritedMethods(MetaClass.java:220)
at groovy.lang.MetaClass.checkInitialised(MetaClass.java:2135)
at groovy.lang.MetaClassRegistry.checkInitialised(MetaClassRegistry.java:171)
at groovy.lang.MetaClassRegistry.<init>(MetaClassRegistry.java:108)
at groovy.lang.MetaClassRegistry.<init>(MetaClassRegistry.java:82)
at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.Invoker.<init>(Invoker.java:82)
at org.codehaus.groovy.runtime.InvokerHelper.<clinit>(InvokerHelper.java:71)
at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method)
at java.lang.Class.forName(Unknown Source)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.Verifier.class$(Verifier.java:119)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.Verifier.visitClass(Verifier.java:122)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit$5.call(CompilationUnit.java:550)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.applyToPrimaryClassNodes(CompilationUnit.java:822)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.classgen(CompilationUnit.java:525)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.compile(CompilationUnit.java:432)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:234)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:203)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:198)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:184)
at expressions.ExpressionFactory.compile(ExpressionFactory.java:207)

and also:

java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError
at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method)
at java.lang.Class.forName(Unknown Source)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.Verifier.class$(Verifier.java:119)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.Verifier.visitClass(Verifier.java:122)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit$5.call(CompilationUnit.java:550)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.applyToPrimaryClassNodes(CompilationUnit.java:822)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.classgen(CompilationUnit.java:525)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.compile(CompilationUnit.java:432)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:234)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:203)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:198)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:184)
at expressions.ExpressionFactory.compile(ExpressionFactory.java:207)

This code was working perfectly with beta-6, but with beta-8 and beta-9 nothing works anymore.

Ludovic,

Your first exception is because you have some conflicting versions of ASM on your classpath. We've upgraded our requirement regarding ASM. And you may have upgraded only the groovy.jar and not the asm jars.
Or other possibility, you're using Hibernate in combination with Groovy, and Hibernate uses an older version of ASM.
But the second exception seems to be the same as others have encountered and explained in GROOVY-670.
We have to review our class loaders code.
If ever you have some information on what's wrong with our codebase, don't hesitate to provide a patch

Isn't this the same problem as described in GROOVY-375 ?

I am trying to use Groovy as a scripting engine for my Eclipse RCP application. The problem seems to be with MetaClass.loadReflectorClass. If "loader" is not an instance of GroovyClassLoader, registry.loadClass is called which uses a GroovyClassLoader based on the MetaClassRegistry's classloader. Instead, a GroovyClassLoader based on "loader" should be used.
GROOVY-375 is now fixed - could you see if this is still an issue please? It could now be fixed?

The fix to GROOVY-375 did not solve my problem. The problem is in MetaClass.getGroovyLoader(). This method has a lengthy comment:

// We have to make sure a class loaded through groovy is always
// able to find a class of the runtime. I assume the classloaders
// are behaving normal and delegate unknown classes to the parent
// classloader. So if no parent has the same classloader as the
// runtime we can't use the normal loader to create the
// GroovyClassLoader

In my context (Eclipse plug-in architecture), the assumption about classloaders behaving "normally" is invalid. The variable "parent" in method getGroovyLoader() ends up being null, so a new GroovyClassLoader based on localLoader is created. This leads to a java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError because this GroovyClassLoader does not see my application classes.

In my case, I would like getGroovyLoader() to create a new GroovyClassLoader based on "loader" anyway, even if it cannot find the parent classloader it is looking for. If I change the method to create a GroovyClassLoader based on "loader" in all cases, it works for me. Note that this was what the original patch from GROOVY-375 did too.

Under which circumstances would it be correct to create a GroovyClassLoader based on localLoader?

If you think it is important to check that "loader" can load the Groovy runtime classes, could you check for this differently? For example, what about this check: loader.loadClass("groovy.lang.MetaClassRegistry")==localLoader.loadClass("groovy.lang.MetaClassRegistry") ? In my case, the two class objects are identical even though "localLoader" is not on the parent chain of "loader".

Same problem here. Calling runtime classes using groovy in an Eclipse plug-in results in ca ClassNotFoundException. I've tried the fix of getGroovyLoader() method that was proposed in the previous and it works:

if (parent==null) {
groovyLoader = new GroovyClassLoader(loader); // use loader instead of localLoader
} else {
groovyLoader = new GroovyClassLoader(loader);
}

Boris / Peter - I've tried to apply a better patch along the lines as you suggest. Basically we always use the 'loader' so long as we can load the MetaClassRegistery class inside it (i.e. it has Groovy somewhere in its hierarchy).

If we can't load groovy, then we know we cannot use the class loader (as things will barf as soon as we try to load stuff) so we use the local class loader instead (the class loader which loaded groovy).

This fix is all in CVS HEAD - I wonder could you give it a spin and see if it fixes your issues please?

I've tried the latest version, but I have a different problem this time (see the stacktrace below). The code worked fine with beta-10 version. The idea is that a groovy class is generated and compiled at runtime. The generated class extends a class that is available in classpath set using CompilerConfiguration#setClasspath(String) method.

General error during class generation: No such class: JRCalculator No such superclass. At [0:0]

groovy.lang.MissingClassException: No such class: JRCalculator No such superclass. At [0:0]
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.getSuperClassNode(ClassNode.java:526)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.implementsInteface(ClassNode.java:498)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.isDerivedFromGroovyObject(ClassNode.java:485)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.Verifier.visitClass(Verifier.java:122)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit$5.call(CompilationUnit.java:550)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.applyToPrimaryClassNodes(CompilationUnit.java:822)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.classgen(CompilationUnit.java:525)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.compile(CompilationUnit.java:432)
...
As so many people are watching this issue, but the last comment is pre beta-10, maybe so of them could test this with our new JSR-02 release and inform all if this is still a problem
The general problem embedding Groovy into an application deployed in BEA WebLogic Server 8.1 SP3 or SP4 appears to be working ok in the JSR-01 release. Haven't tried the JSR-01 release yet.
Still seems to be a problem in JSR-02. See GROOVY-894.
since GROOVY-894 was no real bug I hope other people can test this bug. If noone says something we will close it for the next release

Sorry for not responding earlier. The classloader problems when embedding Groovy into an Eclipse-based application have been solved (I have tested JSR-02 - groovy-all-1.0-jsr-02.jar).

As far as I am concerned, this bug can be closed. Thanks for fixing it!
